basic_info.search_snippet: Rich Lesser is the Global Chair of Boston Consulting Group (BCG). He previously served as BCG's CEO from 2013-2021, a period of exceptional growth for the firm.

detailed_profile.name: Rich Lesser
detailed_profile.city: New York, New York, United States
detailed_profile.position: Global Chair at Boston Consulting Group (BCG)
detailed_profile.about: Rich Lesser is the Global Chair of Boston Consulting Group (BCG). He previously served as BCG's CEO from 2013-2021, a period of exceptional growth for the firm across all regions and practice areas. During his tenure as CEO, Rich oversaw the launch of BCG Digital Ventures, a builder and accelerator of digital businesses; BCG GAMMA, a cutting-edge advanced analytics, machine-learning and AI team; BCG TURN, a rapid performance acceleration unit; and the BCG Center for Climate & Sustainability. As CEO, Rich initiated BCG's pledge to reach net zero climate impact by 2030. Rich currently serves as chief advisor to the World Economic Forum‚Äôs Alliance of CEO Climate Leaders, on the steering committee of the Council for Inclusive Capitalism, on the board of directors of the Centre for Public Impact, as a board member of CO2AI, and is a member of several leading organizations, such as the WEF‚Äôs Community of Chairpersons, the EDISON Alliance, Southern Communities Initiative, among others. He previously served on the Business Roundtable board of directors and WEF's International Business Council. He accelerated BCG‚Äôs strong investments in social impact through its long-standing partnerships, including the World Food Programme, Save the Children, and the World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF), along with many global health and environment initiatives. Rich served as BCG‚Äôs chairman for North and South America from 2009 to 2012 and as head of the New York Metro office system from 2000 to 2009. Prior to joining BCG in 1988, Rich worked in product development at Procter & Gamble. He received an MBA from Harvard Business School and a BSE in chemical engineering from the University of Michigan College of Engineering, where he now serves on the Leadership Advisory Board.

detailed_profile.position: Incoming Associate at Boston Consulting Group
detailed_profile.about: I come from a family of seven siblings. Growing up in this environment shaped me into the person I am right now. I am a current student at Indiana University who considers himself disciplined, empathetic, and self-driven. I have done many different things, but I enjoy the ones related to sports, business, and social impact. Sports helped me become a more disciplined person. Being empathetic has driven me to do social impact activities and be part of different organizations. Finally, when it comes to business, and I want to create something, I am a self-driven person who knows the goal and will get there. I want to use my education at Kelley School of business as a platform to grow, learn and experience new things. I am sure that the path I am taking and my values will set me off for a successful career in the business world.

recommendations: Griffin Myers ‚ÄúIt is a privilege to recommend my friend, colleague, and mentor, Mr. Jon Kaplan. I worked with Jon for nearly 3 years at the Boston Consulting Group in Chicago; I know him well both as a friend and as a professional. He is the consummate professional and leads with three striking qualities: (1) extraordinary depth and breadth of experience, (2) unparalleled skills a listener, and (3) impressive clarity of thought. First, Jon has been providing strategic advisory to leading firms around the globe for nearly his entire professional career. He has worked for numerous consultancies with hundreds of clients, and the results are the same: happy clients and impressive economic results. His experience stretches across all aspects of healthcare, and he has practical insights that drive results for clients. Very simply: I am often skeptical of the value of management consulting services. I am never skeptical of the value of Jon‚Äôs insight and value as an adviser. Second, Jon is the best listener I know. Imagine you are working with Jon: his skill is not simply finishing your sentences or sitting quietly while you talk. He actively listens and facilitates you communicating with him. Jon makes it easy for you to explain complex, often subtle problems. His clients and teams notice this skill; it makes everyone around him better. I work every day to develop this listening skill Jon has demonstrated. Third, Jon thinks and communicates with clarity. He listens well, and then he is able to summarize and simplify with precision and structure. Meetings with Jon never end without absolute clarity on the problem, the solution, and the approach. It is this experience, listening skill, and ability to communicate with clarity that makes Jon the consultant‚Äôs consultant. He is the ultimate professional as well as a friend, mentor, and adviser, and I would recommend him without reservation. For questions, feel free to reach out to me directly at griffinrmyers@gmail.com.‚Äù

Dawj Sangster, Ph.D ‚ÄúJon is such a wonderful individual to work with. No matter what level you were at in the company, Jon was always so pleasant with a great personality and wonderful smile. He brings intelligence, leadership and a wonderful personality to any position he holds, and we certainly wish him the very best in all he sets out to do!!!!‚Äù

She recently sat down with BCG senior partner Sharon Marcil to discuss what motivated her to take on the position, as well as some of the associated challenges she‚Äôs encountered and lessons she‚Äôs learned.

publications.title: How a Google Veteran Is Bringing Government into the Digital Age
publications.description: Governments around the world are grappling with the rapid pace of technological advancement‚Äîwith varying degrees of success. In the US, the drive to bring the government into the digital age is being led by Matt Cutts who became Acting Administrator of the US Digital Service in early 2017. Cutts sat down recently with Sharon Marcil, a BCG senior partner and the leader of the firm‚Äôs Public Sector practice in the Americas, to discuss the challenges and opportunities facing the USDS‚Äîand why he‚Äôs not quite ready to leave.

publications.title: Four Ways for the US President-Elect to Hit the Ground Running

detailed_profile.name: Julia Howarth
detailed_profile.position: Associate at Boston Consulting Group
detailed_profile.about: As a student, I am continuously looking to take the skills that I am learning in the classroom and find ways to apply them through research or industry experience. I have a very strong desire to help people and leave every environment that I am in better than the way I found it. That drive has now led me to the field of medical devices and using mechanical engineering skills to innovate and improve the lives of patients. Through research opportunities at school, I have been exposed to academic writing and publication, applications of MATLAB, FEA simulations, statistical analysis of data, and direct patient care. Through my internship at Baxter, I was able to see the industrial side of product development and run exploratory and Class C testing, investigate root causes of imperfections, create detailed business cases for VIP‚Äôs, and work in a deadline-oriented environment. With the broad range of skills through my education in mechanical engineering, I have pivoted towards Business Management Consulting with Boston Consulting Group. The complex problem solving, teamwork focus, and open-communication and growth has made my time there invaluable, and I am excited for it to continue! When I am not working or studying, I am incredibly active. I am continuing to run the 800 post-collegiately but I also love to trail-run, hike, rock-climb, paddleboard, and ski.

experience.title: Undergraduate Researcher
experience.description: Drip irrigation is a tool used to aid farmers in increasing crop production while decreasing water and energy consumption. Pressure-compensating (PC) drip emitters are especially effective as they enable uniform water delivery to all crops regardless of pressure losses in the pipe. Even with the proven effectiveness of drip irrigation, it is often not adopted by small farmers due to large upfront and maintenance costs along with a lack of trust in the system. My work focused on increasing clog-resistance within the drip emitter to impact effectiveness, longevity, and drip adoption. Day-to-day this consisted of...- completing fluid calculations- computer-aided designs on Solidworks- running fluid-models- in-person fluid tests- technical writing and presentation skills
experience.description_html:
Drip irrigation is a tool used to aid farmers in increasing crop production while decreasing water and energy consumption. Pressure-compensating (PC) drip emitters are especially effective as they enable uniform water delivery to all crops regardless of pressure losses in the pipe. experience.title: Undergraduate Research Assistant
experience.description: I worked with an MIT graduate student on the production of sockets for lower-leg amputees. Our goal was to improve and refine a MATLAB code that could take in MRI scans, tissue analysis, and weight of a patient and output a CAD model of a socket specific to that patient. If this code continues to be improved upon it would greatly decrease the time and cost required of a patient. The skills I learned during this experience are listed below. ‚Ä¢	MATLAB‚Ä¢	Statistical analysis of data ‚Ä¢	Direct patient care

volunteer_experience.info: In 2012, my school district, Duneland, hosted a referendum for which members of the community voted to slightly increase property taxes in order to provide additional funds to Duneland. An election to renew said referendum occurred this past May. In January, a former teacher of mine invited me to join a group of students he was putting together with the intention of spreading public awareness about the referendum. The goal of the operation was to win the vote so that Duneland could maintain its‚Ä¶ Show more In 2012, my school district, Duneland, hosted a referendum for which members of the community voted to slightly increase property taxes in order to provide additional funds to Duneland. An election to renew said referendum occurred this past May. In January, a former teacher of mine invited me to join a group of students he was putting together with the intention of spreading public awareness about the referendum. The goal of the operation was to win the vote so that Duneland could maintain its funding and continue to offer various programs. Most of the other surrounding districts had already voted for their own educational referenda, making it a matter of pride as well. The cause was spearheaded by PAC, a team of Duneland employees as well as some other prominent community members. Our student team, SLAC, was created to be a diverse team, composed of students of various extracurriculars (I represented the academic teams and choirs), with the purpose of supporting PAC and reaching our peers. I served as the SLAC representative to PAC; I attended the meetings of both and informed each about the other‚Äôs agenda. First, we in SLAC provided stations at which eligible students could register to vote at school. We know of about 350 students that registered at our stations. We then visited students during study halls with a presentation that outlined the positives of the tax increase and what they and their parents gained from its existence. We also helped PAC in canvassing neighborhoods and advertising at various community functions, garnering further support. We ultimately succeeded, winning the vote with nearly 75%. By participating in the campaign, I saw that citizens really can make a difference in their community. It is often difficult to see individual efforts bear fruit in the national or state public affairs, but we were able to see our efforts have a real impact on our community. Show less

detailed_profile.name: Jean Whitney
detailed_profile.position: IT Director Product Owner at The Boston Consulting Group (BCG)
detailed_profile.about: Summary: I am an experienced IT professional with agile, management, collaboration and learning technology skills, spanning three continents, 27 years and roles from programmer to systems manager to product owner. Professional Experience: I have a broad range of experience, covering eight years in systems management, sixteen years in management consulting and learning technology and three in publishing. I currently am a Director Product Owner for Boston Consulting Group. My responsibilities include operations & enhancement of various identity security platforms. Previously, on a project by project basis, I managed a teams of up to 25 technologists, analysts and architects delivering learning strategy, or implementing learning management systems and other learning technology for clients. This includes managing vendor staff and coordinating between various project workstreams. I completed the entire Learning Management Systems (LMS) implementation cycle several times, from procurement, requirements definition, system design and installation, population of the database and end-user release. I implemented integrated eLearning systems including LMS, virtual classroom, on-line help and web-based training as well as other Human Capital Management solutions. I assisted large corporations to consider their learning and HR technology options, and wrote strategy papers based on comprehensive research into their infrastructure. Specialties: Agile Product Owner skills including prioritization, backlog management, KPIs/OKRs, quarterly and annual planning, big room planning and retrospectives. Also, as-is assessment of learning functions, learning strategy, learning technology strategy, collaboration technology, learning technology integration, learning management systems, project management, virtual classroom facilitation, social software, Saba, implementation management

recommendations: Amy Dickinson ‚ÄúI had the absolute pleasure of working under the leadership of Sayra at Dell Technologies, and I cannot emphasize enough what an incredible experience it was. Sayra exemplifies all the qualities of an exceptional leader. She possesses a remarkable ability to inspire and motivate her team members, fostering a positive and collaborative work environment. Her leadership style is characterized by trust, open communication, and genuine care for the professional and personal development of her employees. While in the Director of Marketing position at Dell, Sayra demonstrated an exceptional ability to orchestrate complex initiatives with remarkable success. She spearheaded a team of eleven talented individuals and her leadership style encouraged autonomy, creativity, and innovation, resulting in the delivery of exceptional outcomes. Under Sayra‚Äôs guidance, we developed an engaging, informative, and memorable event strategy that not only captivated our target audience but also delivered on crucial marketing-qualified leads and sales-qualified leads. With a budget exceeding $15 million, she expertly allocated resources to maximize our impact, ensuring every dollar was utilized effectively and efficiently. One of Sayra's greatest strengths lies in her ability to collaborate across diverse teams and build consensus to execute against the event plans. She fostered strong working relationships with stakeholders from various departments, including marketing, sales, operations, and finance. By leveraging her exceptional communication and negotiation skills, Sayra ensured that all parties were aligned, fully supported the event objectives, and worked together seamlessly. Furthermore, Sayra is incredibly approachable and easy-going, creating a positive and inclusive work environment. She actively encourages open dialogue, listens attentively to diverse perspectives, and makes informed decisions that consider the best interests of both the team and the organization. Her ability to make everyone feel heard and valued created a harmonious and collaborative atmosphere, where ideas could flow freely, and teamwork thrived. I am truly grateful for the opportunity to have worked under Sayra's leadership. Her guidance, trust, and easy-going nature made my time at Dell an incredibly rewarding experience, and I would not be where I am in my career today without Sayra's mentorship. I have no doubt that she will continue to excel in any leadership position she undertakes, and I wholeheartedly recommend her to any organization seeking an exceptional leader who fosters a supportive and high-performing team culture.‚Äù

Becky Levanger ‚ÄúSayra was my director (my manager's manager) when I first graduated from business school. I was in the Demand Gen marketing team which she managed along with the events team for the Enterprise Technology Division (pre-Dell acquisition). Since working at Dell EMC I spent 4 years working in events and have a deep appreciation for how exceptional Sayra is. She knows the industry backwards and forwards. She knows how to position the future possibilities of technological growth and innovation. She knows how to get people excited and feel like they are a part of something. I used so many of the things I saw modeled and learned from Sayra at Google in our Next and Partner Summit events. Beyond her skill set, Sayra is also just an absolutely phenomenal person. I adored working for her and was very sad to leave her team, in spite of the fact that I was coming to my dream job at Google. She and I were work out buddies, encouraged each other to be healthy, and actually started a 6am morning workout class that all of our other team members eventually started joining! She is the kind of person you hope to have as a friend, and the kind of boss you know you are so lucky to have. I have no hesitation in recommending her, and would be happy to be contacted in regards to any role that she is being considered for.‚Äù

detailed_profile.name: Brian Barnett
detailed_profile.position: Global Real Estate Director at Boston Consulting Group (BCG)
detailed_profile.about: Brian is responsible for real estate strategy, transactions, and project delivery for BCG‚Äôs North and South American office portfolio. As a trusted business partner to senior leaders, he aligns real estate execution with long-term business objectives and growth plans while adhering to global portfolio targets to optimize the portfolio. Managing a team of program managers located across the US who are responsible for transactions and project delivery, he supports each project's strategic plan, acts as a key escalation point for transaction negotiation, and is a valued thought partner throughout design/construction.

Throughout each project it was required to work with all internal stakeholders and coordinate BCG's global real estate vendor's activities. Brian supported the strategic management of the company's real estate portfolio performance on a regional and global level.

positions.subtitle: Newmark Knight Frank
positions.description: In the role of Managing Director, East Region Lead for the Global Corporates Services (GCS) group, Brian formulated proactive, innovative, and solutions-oriented strategies for complex and diverse real estate portfolios. The delivery of integrated solutions that align global real estate objectives with business goals drove the execution of all service delivery. He worked closely with clients to improve their CRE processes and utilize best-in-class technology solutions to increase effectiveness and drive efficiencies. Over the course of his time at Newmark, he completed over 300 projects covering over 3M SF across the globe over all major property types (office, industrial, retail) inclusive of site selections, relocations, lease renewals, expansions, subleases, and terminations. His role evolved into a management position over time as he increased his number of clients, teamed with direct reports, and pursued business development opportunities.

projects.title: Birth Order and Self-Esteem: A between-family study
projects.description: I applied for the Science Research program in my high school because I have always enjoyed the STEM fields and wanted a chance to participate in some hands-on research. As a middle child, the effect of birth order on self-esteem had always fascinated me. I designed my own study, got IRB (Internal Revenue Board) approval, conducted my surveys and wrote a research paper summarizing my results. The entire research process was an invaluable learning experience. I learned firsthand that research does not always proceed as planned. I am proud of my persistence and the result of my endeavor.

detailed_profile.name: Andy Kaufmann
detailed_profile.position: Principal at Boston Consulting Group (BCG)
detailed_profile.about: I am a Principal at Boston Consulting Group (BCG) and a proud graduate of Washington University in St. Louis, where I studied Computer Science and Healthcare Management. My work focuses on the intersection of healthcare and technology - a passion I‚Äôm fortunate to pursue both professionally and personally. I often say I‚Äôm lucky enough to spend my weekdays working on the same things that I explore on weekends: Healthcare, Technology, Product Management, and Leadership. I specialize in supporting clients on projects with strong digital and technological components in healthcare, focusing on payers and providers, and navigating complex environments to deliver impact. With a background in engineering and technology, I bring a practical, hands-on approach to problem-solving, helping clients drive results in multidisciplinary team settings. My ability to communicate effectively across diverse disciplines ensures that solutions are innovative, actionable, and widely embraced. Outside of client work, I am passionate about recruiting, training, and mentoring the next generation of consultants at BCG. A particular focus of mine is helping teams harness the power of Generative AI to enhance the quality and efficiency of their work, setting them up for long-term success in an ever changing landscape. Beyond work, you‚Äôll often find me in the kitchen trying out new recipes, on the trail running, or hitting the slopes for a day of skiing.

detailed_profile.name: Taylor C. Robertson
detailed_profile.city: Washington, District of Columbia, United States
detailed_profile.position: Associate at Boston Consulting Group
detailed_profile.about: We become what we design ourselves to be. I‚Äôm an intensely curious young professional with the constant motivation to innovate. I began my career in Washington, D.C. as an Associate with Boston Consulting Group, starting in January 2024. Post-grad, I traveled for 4 months through twenty countries in Europe and Northern Africa. I possess an intense dedication to self-development and am eager to dive into my industries of interest (including Travel & Tourism, Retail/Consumer, Real Estate, Start-Ups, Technology, Education, and Publishing) and begin a career with meaning through purposeful work that aligns with my desire to reinvent around me for the good of clients, my communities, and make progress towards a more efficient & content world. I believe that nothing should be done a certain way solely because that was how it was done previously, but believe that we should utilize the knowledge and practices that have been built before us which allow us to succeed quicker than we can alone. Whether it is pitching a business plan, creating a product prototype, laying out a multi-sheet Excel model, or writing a novel: I always come with fresh ideas and energy. Please feel free to contact me at taylorcrobertson@gmail.com.

publications.title: The M&A Way into Distributed Energy
publications.subtitle: Boston Consulting Group
publications.description: Distributed energy resources (DER) companies have emerged as a real force in thepower industry. Recent advances in battery storage, smart-home technology, andenergy management devices, as well as a growing thirst for green energy amongcustomers and policymakers, are making DER an attractive alternative to traditional grid distribution and meter-based systems.The M&A WayTo take advantage of the opportunity that DER holds‚Äîthe market is growing bydouble digits annually‚Äîincumbents would be wise to pursue acquisitions of DERcompanies. Although expanding, the DER segment is still immature and fragmented, populated by numerous small startups. Established utilities have a wide varietyof potential partners with which to enter the market quickly.First-Mover AdvantagesPower companies that strike first to increase scale, expand DER R&D, and developnew skill sets in DER applications can rapidly realize a competitive edge. By bringing the latest technology and a lean cost structure to the DER market, incumbentscould gain first-mover advantages and become dominant in a segment that promises to become as palatable to consumers as the traditional power segment is today.

organizations.title: Additional Boards
organizations.description: Gerri served on the advisory board for the Center for Executive Women Senior Leadership Program at Northwestern University‚Äôs Kellogg School of Management. detailed_profile.position: Associate at Boston Consulting Group
detailed_profile.about: We become what we design ourselves to be. I‚Äôm an intensely curious young professional with the constant motivation to innovate. I began my career in Washington, D.C. as an Associate with Boston Consulting Group, starting in January 2024. Post-grad, I traveled for 4 months through twenty countries in Europe and Northern Africa. I possess an intense dedication to self-development and am eager to dive into my industries of interest (including Travel & Tourism, Retail/Consumer, Real Estate, Start-Ups, Technology, Education, and Publishing) and begin a career with meaning through purposeful work that aligns with my desire to reinvent around me for the good of clients, my communities, and make progress towards a more efficient & content world. I believe that nothing should be done a certain way solely because that was how it was done previously, but believe that we should utilize the knowledge and practices that have been built before us which allow us to succeed quicker than we can alone. Whether it is pitching a business plan, creating a product prototype, laying out a multi-sheet Excel model, or writing a novel: I always come with fresh ideas and energy. Please feel free to contact me at taylorcrobertson@gmail.com.

detailed_profile.name: Andy Kaufmann
detailed_profile.position: Principal at Boston Consulting Group (BCG)
detailed_profile.about: I am a Principal at Boston Consulting Group (BCG) and a proud graduate of Washington University in St. Louis, where I studied Computer Science and Healthcare Management. My work focuses on the intersection of healthcare and technology - a passion I‚Äôm fortunate to pursue both professionally and personally. I often say I‚Äôm lucky enough to spend my weekdays working on the same things that I explore on weekends: Healthcare, Technology, Product Management, and Leadership. I specialize in supporting clients on projects with strong digital and technological components in healthcare, focusing on payers and providers, and navigating complex environments to deliver impact. With a background in engineering and technology, I bring a practical, hands-on approach to problem-solving, helping clients drive results in multidisciplinary team settings. My ability to communicate effectively across diverse disciplines ensures that solutions are innovative, actionable, and widely embraced. Outside of client work, I am passionate about recruiting, training, and mentoring the next generation of consultants at BCG. A particular focus of mine is helping teams harness the power of Generative AI to enhance the quality and efficiency of their work, setting them up for long-term success in an ever changing landscape. Beyond work, you‚Äôll often find me in the kitchen trying out new recipes, on the trail running, or hitting the slopes for a day of skiing.

recommendations: M. Eric Johnson ‚ÄúI enjoyed working with Emily during her two years at Vanderbilt. publications.title: Exploiting length-dependent effects for the design of single-material systems with enhanced thermal transport properties
publications.subtitle: International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer
publications.description: Topology optimization approaches for thermal transport problems generally rely on the presence of high contrast in thermal conductivity between constituent materials. Even though this might result in topo- logical configurations that are optimal according to some desired thermal metric, the resulting systems might be impractical from a mechanical standpoint: high contrast in thermal conductivity generally translates into disparate ranges of thermal expansion, which in turn may lead to mechanical failure. In this paper, we focus on the combination of multi-scale modeling and topology optimization techniques for the design of polycrystalline single-material systems with enhanced thermal transport properties. Spatial variation of the length-dependent thermal conductivity is achieved by grading the characteristic grain size of the microstructure. We adopt a multi-scale approach to compute the attainable range of thermal conductivity due to grain-size effect, given maximum and minimum grain sizes and an operating temperature range. Then, we utilize an adaptive topology optimization technique to obtain an optimal grain size distribution, while accounting for manufacturing constraints. Through a series of specific examples, we demonstrate the extent to which thermal transport properties can be optimized without resorting to the adoption of multi-material systems.

publications.title: A length-dependent model for the thermomechanical response of ceramics
publications.subtitle: Journal of the Mechanics and Physics of Solids
publications.description: We present a length-dependent model for the thermomechanical response of ceramics through a concurrent multiscale scheme that accounts for: (i) the locally varying values of the sub-grain thermal conductivity tensor due to the interaction of phonons with microstructural features such as grain boundaries, and (ii) a continuum model of thermal stresses that explicitly resolves the polycrystalline structure of the material. At the sub-grain level, we compute the values of the thermal conductivity tensor using the Boltzmann transport equation under the relaxation time approximation. At the continuum level, the polycrystalline structure of the specimen is resolved explicitly by a finite element mesh and the texture of the polycrystal is assumed to be given. At this level, we adopt a Fourier model of heat conduction which utilizes values of thermal conductivity obtained at the lower scale. The mechanical response of the grains is modeled as elastic and anisotropic. The capabilities of the model are demonstrated through a series of examples, which highlight the potential of our approach for designing materials with improved thermomechanical response.

publications.title: Building a Better Customer Insight Capability
publications.subtitle: bcgperspectives.com
publications.description: CEOs and customer insight (CI) professionals often point to tight budgets to explain why CI is not integrated into core business decisions and processes. But budgets alone do not determine CI effectiveness. Nor does the size of the team.To become a true source of competitive advantage, a CI function should control its spending and set its priorities, including what it is not doing, and gain alignment.It must also find the right people to serve as leaders and team members. A strategic point of view is essential.Visit insightsassessment.bcg.com to evaluate a CI function and learn how it can make an outcomes-driven contribution to the business.

publications.title: Digital or Die: The Choice for Luxury Brands
publications.subtitle: bcgperspectives.com
publications.description: It may not be widely recognized as such just yet, but digital technology is probably one of the best things to happen to luxury brands in a long time.Digital is happening fast and forcefully, whether brands are ready for it or not. It enables new products and services. It opens up opportunities to create personalized offers and provide bespoke services to many more customers. Its distribution channels widen the playing field for luxury brands, allowing them to reach consumers not reached before and to engage with customers online in markets where a brand has no stores. In the US alone, consumers anticipate spending 20% to 35% of their total outlays online in the next few years, according to research by The Boston Consulting Group. (See The Reciprocity Principle: How Millennials Are Changing the Face of Marketing Forever, BCG Focus, January 2014.)But not all brands are there yet. In fact, luxury lags other consumer sectors when it comes to understanding and applying digital technologies. Disney, Nike, Nordstrom‚Äîthese are just a handful of the household names that have mastered digital. For more than a few luxury brands, then, the issue really is do or die: the speed of technology development is endangering their current business models faster than you can say ‚Äúcelebrity-chef-catered safari.‚Äù

publications.title: Why Companies Can‚Äôt Turn Customer Insights into Growth
publications.subtitle: BCG.perspectives

publications.title: The Introverted Corporation
publications.subtitle: BCG
publications.description: Customer centricity is an imperative in a rapidly changing competitive environment, but many companies focus inward.Most major business decisions do not reflect insights into customers.To overcome introversion, companies must look beyond obvious data sources and mine them better than the competition does.This article is the first in a series exploring the effective development of customer insights in large organizations.

publications.title: The CFDA Guidebook to Showing In-Season
publications.subtitle: CFDA
publications.description: The Boston Consulting Group study on the future of New York Fashion Week is now complete. As part of the CFDA‚Äôs continued commitment to supporting designers as they define what is right for their brands, we created a comprehensive guidebook to utilize if you decide to hold in-season events. The guidebook is a tool to begin meaningful conversations about your business strategy and how to navigate the transition seasons.

publications.title: THE RESULTS ARE IN: Examing the Future of New York Fashion Week
publications.subtitle: CFDA
publications.description: New York Fashion Week opens the season of global fashion weeks. Its purpose is for designers to show their upcoming collections, for press to review it and for buyers to place orders. Many American designers will continue to take orders from buyers in London, Milan and Paris. These collections are then delivered to stores and available for consumers to buy four to six months later.In recent years, evolutions in technology, consumer behaviors and needs, weather and physical seasons, and retail have challenged the role and impact of the current Fashion System:As the organization representing American designers and the organizer of the official New York Fashion Week schedule, it is CFDA‚Äôs responsibility to evaluate the purpose of New York Fashion Week. The intent of the CFDA study undertaken with The Boston Consulting Group in January was to question the status quo for our market, stimulate a dialogue in the American fashion industry and move towards long-term solutions together.The unanimous consensus among our interviewees: the time is ripe for change in our market. ‚ÄòIn-season relevancy‚Äô emerged as a recurring idea. Beyond fashion shows, the delivery cycle and subsequent markdown cadence at retail emerged as a critical issue that needs to be addressed in our market to better match the actual, physical season and our consumers‚Äô behaviors and needs. CFDA highlighted the statistics and exhibits here and answered the most frequently asked questions here.

publications.title: The Reciprocity Principle: How Millennials Are Changing the Face of Marketing Forever
publications.subtitle: BCG Perspectives by The Boston Consulting Group
publications.description: Millennials represent the consumer market of the future. U.S. Millennials already account for an estimated $1.3 trillion in direct annual spending. It is perhaps more important that this generation is transforming consumer marketing itself.Millennials engage with brands more personally, extensively and emotionally than do older consumers, and social media and mobile devices greatly amplify their feedback.Millennials also expect a reciprocal, two-way relationship with companies, and want brands to reflect their values. We call this the reciprocity principle.Companies can expect that a positive brand experience will prompt Millennials to take favorable public action on behalf of their brand. A bad‚Äîor even just disappointing‚Äîexperience can turn a Millennial into a vocal critic who will spread the negative word through social media, reviews, and blogs.In marketing, as in pop culture, Millennials are leading indicators of large-scale changes in future consumer behavior. As a result, this generational transition is ushering in the end of consumer marketing as we have long known it. The good old rational, linear "push" approach to marketing will never be the same again.If they have not already begun to do so, companies must make marketing to Millennials a top strategic priority and begin to master the art of two-way reciprocal marketing. Companies are already finding that pushing consistent, prepackaged brand messages to the masses through traditional media is not as effective and cost efficient as it once was‚Äîcertainly not with Millennials, nor increasingly with Gen-Xers and boomers.

publications.title: Why Emerging-Market Consumers Remain Bullish: Keeping an Eye on the Prize
publications.subtitle: BCG Perspectives by The Boston Consulting Group

publications.title: The Trust Advantage: How to Win with Big Data
publications.subtitle: BCG Perspectives by The Boston Consulting Group
publications.description: Some organizations will excel at creating trust, and some will not. We estimate that those that manage this issue well should be able to increase the amount of consumer data they can access by at least five to ten times in most countries. And if they can generate meaningful insights from this information and execute an effective big-data strategy, the resulting torrent of newly available data could shift market shares and accelerate innovation. This performance boost is what we call the ‚Äútrust advantage.‚Äù

publications.title: New York Fashion Week The Study: Stats and Exhibits
publications.subtitle: CFDA
publications.description: New York Fashion Week opens the season of global Fashion Weeks. Its purpose is for designers to show their upcoming collections, for press to review those collections and for buyers to place orders. Many American designers will continue to take orders from buyers in London, Milan and Paris during subsequent weeks. These collections are then delivered to stores and available for consumers to buy four to six months later.In recent years, evolutions in technology, consumer behaviors, weather, and retail cycle have challenged the role and impact of the current fashion system.As the organization representing American designers and the organizer of the official New York Fashion Week schedule, it is CFDA‚Äôs responsibility to evaluate the purpose of New York Fashion Week. The intent of the CFDA study undertaken with The Boston Consulting Group in January was to question the status quo for our market, bring up all the issues, and stimulate a dialogue in the American fashion industry; it is a first step to then move towards long-term solutions together.Over the past six weeks, more than 50 fashion industry stakeholders, mostly in the U.S., were formally interviewed by The Boston Consulting Group, and dozens more informal conversations have taken place. Of those formal interviews, 20 were designers or fashion executives, 8 wholesalers and online retailers, and 15 editors of both traditional and new media. The remaining 7 included show organizers, casting agents, fashion bloggers, and international fashion trade organizations.

detailed_profile.name: Nicki C.
detailed_profile.position: Administrative Services Leader | Team Builder | Mother of 4 | Marathon Runner | Writer | Boston Consulting Group (BCG)
detailed_profile.about: I currently lead Administrative Services for BCG Nexus Atlanta, Nexus Costa Rica and Dallas. With 30 years at BCG, I started as production assistant before moving into EA and then Senior EA role supported J. Puckett (Managing Director and Senior Partner). J. founded our firm's global education practice and is Global leader of BCG U, the firm's upskilling, reskilling, and talent development offering.. While supporting J., I also managed several teams within BCG‚Äôs South System and have worked with many other BCG partners over my career. Prior to joining BCG, I worked for Morrison Knudsen Engineering. I have a passion for the EA role and the value it brings to organizations. I am a co-author of The Heart of CEO Effectiveness, which reinforces the value and impact the EA role has within an organization. I've written several LinkedIn articles regarding EA role, running and team building. I am also thankful to have my writing that captured my Boston Marathon 2018 running experience highlighted in the Boston Buddies book alongside incredible women like Katherine Switzer and Sarah Sellers, who are an inspiration to me and many others. I am blessed with the chaos of 4 wonderful children and an amazing husband for over 30 years. In my spare time, I‚Äôm and avid runner. I've successfully completed Dallas, BCS, United States Air Force Marathon, San Antonio, Louisiana 2016 & 2018, Boston 2017 & 2018, and Joplin. I'm looking forward to more adventures to come!

publications.subtitle: Boston Consulting Group
publications.description: The role of CEO calls for efficiency and effectiveness in every interaction. High-performing support staffs can help the executives they support achieve these goals while amplifying their reach and sharpening their focus.In this article, we explore how CEO staffs assist their chief executives in identifying, prioritizing, and protecting time, which can make the difference between realized ambition and lost opportunity.

publications.title: Boston Buddies: Boston Marathon 2018: Inspirational Stories about overcoming life's challenges one mile at a time
publications.subtitle: Amazon
publications.description: My 2018 Boston Marathon race report was included in the collection of stories from that day.....April 16, 2018, 26,948 runners huddled up in the little town of Hopkinton Massachusetts 26.2 miles away from the Boston Marathon finish line. The weather forecast called for 38-degree temperatures, two inches of rain, a sustained 15 to 25 miles per hour head wind, and a real feel temperature below freezing. But that was nothing compared to the challenges that many of these runners faced on their journey to the start line. Cancer, ALS, HIV, autism, and divorce are some of the challenges you‚Äôll read about that these runners had to overcome to be able to participate in one of the most prestigious marathons in the world. No one was going to let the weather stand in their way of running a race that meant so much to them in their own unique way.

recommendations: Ed Moore ‚ÄúI had the pleasure of working with Linda for the five years I headed up Internal Audit at Iron Mountain. Linda was a very dynamic leader who took a broad interest in supporting the key initiatives and objectives of the company. Linda essentially developed a strategy for significantly increasing and expanding the remit of the procurement organisation by building very strong relationships with her key stakeholders and hiring very capable and talented resources. She won over some initially skeptical stakeholders who had been used to making their own procurement decisions by listening to their concerns and then demonstrating the added value she and her team could bring toward the management of key supplier relationships. Linda quickly developed a solid reputation as a talented negotiator for the company as well developing a model that excelled at executing against key strategic initiatives. Linda was able to save the company signficant costs while increasing the value of supplier relationships at the same time. I truly appreciated Linda's efforts throughout my time at IRM as she consistently supported risk mitigation strategies and was a very strong advocate for the strengthening internal controls when it was appropriate. I truly believe Linda could add significant value in this area for any company that is looking to improve its procurement and supplier relationships.‚Äù

Rob Reynolds ‚ÄúLinda is an experienced sourcing and procurement executive and a valued business partner who delivers results. We have collaborated on many initiatives and I value her knowledge, expertise, and ability to listen and solve real business challenges. Linda is a true professional who drives results not just through her organization but by driving alignment via providing valuable insights to the business. She is a talented executive who excels at building a highly functioning organization with emphasis on collaboration and business partnership. In a short period of time she transformed our procurement organization into a value add organization and expanded the remit to a true global platform. Amazing leader and great evaluator of talent who understands the value of an engaged team. Absolute pleasure to work with.‚Äù

publications.description: It‚Äôs well known that Procurement functions can provide significant value to the organizations we support. There is no single answer in solving these concerns, as each company has their own revenue and expense priorities to navigate. All that being said, there are some effective levers that procurement functions can tap in order to enable strategic improvements.

publications.title: Functional Requirements of a Web-Based Solution to Engage Diabetic Patients
publications.subtitle: Journal of Mason Graduate Research
publications.description: Studies demonstrate a positive correlation between favorable health outcomes (i.e. patients achieving and sustaining good health) and patients who are engaged with managing their care plan. The advancement and adoption of IT solutions in the health delivery setting has empowered providers to communicate health information with other providers and patients themselves. Patient portals have become the standard health information technology (HIT) tool for engaging patients with their care. As a Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPPA) compliant tool, patient portals have allowed providers to share health information with patients without restraints. However, patient portals have many improvement opportunities in order to truly engage patient with their care. In a broad perspective, there is need for a bi-directional interaction between patients and providers. This paper identifies key issues that have contributed to the dissatisfaction associated with patient portals and requirements that would effectively address these issues. Moreover, this proposal will discuss how an alternate web-based solution can engage a high-risk patient population, diabetics, through functions that will empower patients to manage their health, interact with multiple providers, and benefit from provider outreach efforts.Keywords: patient portal, diabetes, patient engagement, web-based, health IT, healthcare access

positions.title: Onboarding Specialist
positions.description_html:
• Onboarded and processed 322 new hires as the Onboarding Specialist

• Oversaw the “post-offer” portion of the recruitment cycle for all staff positions (Clinical, Administrative, Corporate, Per Diem and Interns) across seven states

• Carried out new hire functions including the creation of offer letters, license verifications, background/driving checks, and reference checks

• Audited new hire paperwork to meet company standards as well as to maintain HIPAA compliance and meet State regulations

• Corresponded with Background Check vendor to track progress/satisfaction of the service and to address inquiries for local Branches

• Collaborated with Developer Analyst to convert new hire paperwork to an electronic system (reduced amount of paper in new hire kits by 51%)

• Scheduled pre-employment physicals, drug screens, and follow up appointments for all new clinical staff

• Provided weekly updates to the Clinical Department to coordinate RN Orientations, and to assist the Operations and Training departments in organizing mentors for new administrative/clerical positions

• Maintained spreadsheets to track candidates during the recruitment cycle

• Presented recruitment reports at internal meetings and conducted orientation for new hires in the Corporate Office

• Coordinated parking for Corporate staff in conjunction with Cushman & Wakefield

recommendations: Dr. Sebastian Gohr ‚ÄúI worked with Justine on a data analytics projects, which involved some heavy data structure building that she was overseeing. She demonstrated smart creativity in problem solving, not just following brute-force approaches, all with an admirable "get-the-job-done right" mentality. Justine is the right person to connect the dots of a (t)ask and identify suitable solutions that match the stakeholder's actual business needs. Thank you for your efforts and the great team collaboration, it was a pleasure! I'd always work again with Justine as Project Manager. Any project, any time!‚Äù

George Lloyd ‚ÄúI am fortunate to have had the opportunity to work with Justine Watt over the last five years. During that time I have come to know Justine as smart, compassionate, driven, focused, fearless and collaborative. From scoping a case to driving a team toward a common goal, she is always quick as a whip, asking probing questions that help to lead to the most logical conclusions. Despite her work ethic and ‚Äòclient first‚Äô mentality, she always considers the unique circumstances of every team player and is the first to appropriately recognize and advocate for work/life balance for the members of her team. As an individual contributor and as a team lead, once on a case, she tunes a laser focus on the task at hand and is always playing a key role in driving to the end goal. Justine is fearless of any task put before her, diving right into the mix without hesitation. That said, she is the first to ensure that all stakeholders and team member perspectives are allowed a forum for consideration in a truly collaborative fashion. Justine is a talented team leader, and I am fortunate to have had the opportunity to partner with her over these years. Sincerely, George Lloyd‚Äù

detailed_profile.name: Andy Levine
detailed_profile.position: Managing Director and Partner at The Boston Consulting Group | Global lead, Airlines
detailed_profile.about: I am a Managing Director and Partner at BCG, where I currently lead our global Airline practice, and focus broadly in travel, covering aviation, lodging, gaming, travel technology, and transport infrastructure. I help clients in the industry fundamentally rethink their strategies across a range of commercial and operational topics. I get most excited by helping bring innovative new ideas, many enabled by digital solutions and advanced analytics. I joined BCG in 2008 and have held a number of roles in my time at the company. I am passionate about advancing the Diversity & Inclusion agenda and helping coach and mentor others as I have been myself. Before BCG, I worked at Caesars Entertainment Corporation and Cornerstone Research. I received my BA in Mathematics (Magna Cum Laude and with distinction in the Major) from Yale University and my MBA from Harvard Business School. Outside of work, I enjoy anything having to do with cooking, theater, or the Miami Dolphins.

publications.title: Steering Consumers to Greener Travel and Tourism Choices
publications.subtitle: BCG
publications.description: Travel and tourism accounts for some 10% of global emissions, a greater share than many other categories. Without intervention, travel and tourism emissions will grow by 5% annually, to 8.4 gigatons of CO2 emissions in 2030. To reduce the industry‚Äôs carbon footprint, travel and tourism companies must persuade consumers to make more sustainable travel choices. That‚Äôs a daunting task: In travel and tourism, relative to other categories, the number of macrochoices (a green class of service, for example) and microchoices (choosing local products) that consumers face is particularly vast, and these choices often come with unique nuances.To effect change among consumers, companies should follow a three-step process: understand the drivers of choice, innovate to create sustainable offerings, and promote sustainable choices.

publications.title: Moving Medical Affairs To The Pharma Forefront
publications.subtitle: In Vivo
publications.description: Straddling the R&D and commercial sides of a typical pharma organization means medical affairs is naturally positioned to play an expanded role along the full pharma value chain. The combination of exploding data from internal and external sources, and a stronger focus on value and outcomes, has reshaped the requirements and expectations for drug development and commercialization businesses.The fast-evolving health care landscape is lifting the importance of medical affairs at biopharma companies, necessitating leaders to rethink the capabilities, talent, metrics, and focus they bring to their jobs. As a number of high-impact trends accelerate in the coming years, the opportunity for medical affairs functions to play a more active and influential role both internally and externally will increase.In Vivo explores the overarching themes and questions from a roundtable discussion among senior medical affairs leaders from 14 top biopharma companies. The session was facilitated by The Boston Consulting Group and supported by surveys and interviews with larger groups of medical affairs leaders and professionals.

detailed_profile.name: Maurice Berns
detailed_profile.position: Managing Director & Senior Partner at Boston Consulting Group l Chair, Center for Energy Impact
detailed_profile.about: I have worked in the energy industry since 1993 and joined Boston Consulting Group in 2001. I am a core member of the firm‚Äôs Energy practice leadership and Chair of BCG's Center for Energy Impact. Throughout my career, I have helped leading public and private sector companies in the oil, gas, power, and renewables sectors, with advice spanning the full energy value chain from the energy source through to the end consumer. I help my clients identify solutions to some of the most pertinent strategic challenges. My passions are to define innovative solutions and leverage opportunities that arise from energy transition, digital approaches, and value chain integration to create future shareholder value. I actively develop opportunities for networking and professional development within the industry, where I facilitate CEO and senior leadership dialogue and engage with media, universities, and external conferences to share my insights. Before joining BCG, I worked with an independent energy trader in Germany and spent several years with Wintershall in Argentina. While at Wintershall, I worked in oil and gas marketing and later in business development, including planning and commercial implementation of LPG and pipeline projects. I earned an MBA in Finance from The Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania, where I was a Palmer Scholar (top 5% of class). I earned a BA from Duke University (magna cum laude).

publications.title: A Blueprint for the Energy Transition
publications.subtitle: Boston Consulting Group
publications.description: Society has gone through energy transitions in the past‚Äîbut nothing like this one. To limit global warming to 1.5¬∞C above preindustrial levels, we must ramp up renewables and other low-carbon solutions at warp speed.

publications.title: The Last Oil Price Boom May Be in Sight
publications.subtitle: Boston Consulting Group
publications.description: As the world emerges from the COVID-19 crisis, an oil price boom is looking increasingly likely. The market conditions that create the boom will also compress its path‚Äîwith surging demand coinciding with a shortage of supply‚Äîand the price expansion will not last long. Despite the boom‚Äôs relatively short duration, producers and users of oil will need to plan ahead to tap opportunities to prepare for a postpandemic, lower-carbon era and mitigate the risks of higher prices.

publications.title: In a Warming World, How Should Big Oil Navigate the Future?
publications.subtitle: BCG
publications.description: With the production and consumption of oil and natural gas products accounting for more than 40% of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, oil and gas companies are confronted with mounting pressure for change.Uncertainty about the speed and scope of the energy transition ‚Äì due to variables including future government policies, demand for hydrocarbons, and the pace at which technological advances and consumer attitudes will evolve ‚Äì make it difficult for companies to craft a coherent response, however. This is the finding of a new report, ‚ÄúIn a Warming World, How Should Big Oil Navigate the Future?‚Äù

publications.title: Big Oil: Toughen It Out, or Business Model Reboot?
publications.subtitle: The Boston Consulting Group and Morgan Stanley
publications.description: Big Oil‚Äôs operating model has been under pressure in recent years as the majors face mounting competition from more specialized independents and as lower oil prices have crimped margins. For the majors, costs have risen and returns have fallen. However, the days of Big Oil are by no means over. Its unique blend of technical capability, capacity for risk, global reach, and financial strength will play an important role in oil and gas development in the years ahead, according to a new report by The Boston Consulting Group and Morgan Stanley Research.The report, Big Oil: Toughen It Out, or Business Model Reboot?, shows how Big Oil‚Äôs model must evolve for it to maintain its relevance
